title: Mexico hit by second shooting in two days after 14 armed civilians were killed by the military
text:
A gun battle between the military and armed civilians left 15 people dead in southwestern Mexico on Tuesday, the second mass killing to shake the country in as many days.

Security forces responding to the presence of a rifle-totting group were met with fire approximately at 5:15pm near a medical clinic in Tepochica, Guerrero,

Guerrero state public security spokesman Roberto Álvarez said 14 civilians and one soldier died in the shootout not too far from Iguala, a city notorious for the 2014 disappearances of 43 student teachers.

Grim photographs of the gunfight showed two slain civilians, one of them hanging limply off the side of a battered pick-up truck that had been riddled with bullets as security forces patrolled the area.

Mexican National Guard soldiers safeguard a street in the southwestern state of Guerrero where a shooting between the military and armed civilians left 15 people dead on Tuesday. One soldier was reported dead

Mexican authorities said 14 armed civilians were killed during a standoff with the military

The body of an armed civilians hangs out from the side of a window following a gunfight with the military in southwestern Mexico on Tuesday

The incident occurred after suspected cartel gunmen killed 13 police and wounded nine others Monday morning in the neighboring state of Michoacán.

President Andrés Manuel López Obrador blamed the deadly ambush on past administrations for Mexico's chronic violence.

However, the latest carnage is likely to increase pressure on López Obrador to get a grip on a problem he pledged to tackle when he took office last December.

Guerrero and Michoacán are two of Mexico's most violent and lawless states, where rival drug gangs have battled to control smuggling routes to the Pacific and interior of the country.

The leftist López Obrador told a news conference the attack in Michoacán was 'very regrettable' but reiterated that his commitment to greater spending on security and fighting the root causes of violence would eventually pay dividends.

'I'm optimistic we'll secure peace ... we're completely dedicated to this issue, but (past governments) allowed it to grow,' said López Obrador, who has criticized past efforts for taking a confrontational approach to battling crime.

Guerrero state police officers stand near the site of a gunfight where members of the Mexican military killed 14 armed civilians

Homicides in Mexico this year are on track to surpass last year's record.

Photos of the Michoacán crime scene on social media showed bullet-riddled police vehicles set on fire, as well as bodies of dead officers on the ground.

After taking office, López Obrador created a militarized National Guard police force of 70,000 to contain the violence.

But many of the National Guard have instead been deployed to police Mexico's borders to placate United States President Donald Trump, who has threatened to impose tariffs if López Obrador does not reduce the flow of U.S.-bound migrants from Central America.

The city of Iguala pitched Mexico's chronic security problems into the glare of international media after the 43 trainee teachers were abducted by a drug gang in cahoots with corrupt local police on the night of Sept. 26, 2014.

The resulting scandal battered the reputation of Mexico's former president and helped propel López Obrador into office.

The last government said the drug gang killed and incinerated the youths, although investigators only ever definitively identified the remains of one of them.
description: The Mexican military responded to the presence of armed civilians and were met with fire before killing 14 gang members Tuesday. One solider was reported dead.
